 I think this goes to the heart of the problem though Wez. In some of the interviews with this childs classmates and friends, it was stated that this kid had made statements that he "hated his life", "hated his father", and "wished he could die". How can anyone who ever heard one of these statements look him/herself in the mirror now? These are huge red flags, especially when heard from one person repeatedly. Sure, maybe nobody pictured him actually taking the exact actions that he did, but that is not something you sit around thinking about on a regualr basis..."I wonder if Billy is going to bring a gun into school tomorrow and get killed by the SWAT team?". However, with the warning flags this kid was throwing up, people should have been saying..."Hmmm...he seems very troubled, and sounds like someone who could end up hurting himself or others, perhaps I should get him some help before it's too late". We have seen this over and over in our country over the last 15 years. Columbine, Jonesboro, etc. The warnings are there, we just don't seem to pick up on them, or don't seem to take them seriously even when we do hear them. I think this, combined with the apathetic attitude of "It's not my job to watch over him" is what is leading these kids to do the things they are doing. We need to start listening to these kids. While I thought Bowling for Columbine was generally a piece of trash, I did really like the quote by M. Manson of all people. When asked what he would have said to the 2 columbine shooters if he had been able to talk to them prior to the incident, he said "I wouldn't have said anything, I would have listened to them".
